If a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (e.g., if it crosses a mountain range or a river, or if it settles on a new island so that it cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years the two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely beyond the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has “effects” on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
It can be said that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.
The widespread ownership of cars also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the field of medicine to repair damaged bodies.

Bridles are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet may get caught in them.
If a rider falls from the horse and becomes entangled in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse gallops on. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a relatively narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a stirrup leash to fall as soon as it is pulled backwards by a falling rider.
